Topic.Title: It took a few yearz, but the optionz scam iz so blantantly obvious to retailerz that ....

Message.Msg: Shares to be shorted are typically borrowed from an account within the same broker, and usually without charge (but for some highly demanded short stocks there can be fees and interest charged (which the lender of the shares and the broker probably split). If there is no charge for borrowing, the broker will still benefit from the fact that the cash received by the short seller is tied up in margin without earning interest for the short seller. The money will actually be earning interest for the broker, but they won’t give you any of that money. When you opened an account with a broker, you probably signed an agreement allowing them to borrow shares out of your account. Therefore, it is legal. When shares are sold short, the new buyer gets ownership of the actual shares and in a second set of books, an “IOU” is placed in the share lender’s account replacing the number of shares that were sold short. The share lender, will not see the “IOU”, as it will just look like he still owns the shares when he checks his account. The short seller will show a negative number of shares to offset the “IOU”. The result is that for every new share shorted, an additional long share is "created". For each short share, two people will show a long position in their account for that share; the person from whom the share was borrowed and the person who bought the share from the short seller. The short seller’s account will show a negative for each share shorted.

Topic.Title: Who iz gonna hold their tulip bulbz too long?

Message.Msg: thanks for elaborating on your views, sybil. How do you determine a responsible short position? and what are the things you look for when determining a stock is a good short? if you want to find one of these dogs at 10 or 30, are the criteria you look for when screening stocks? How about short funds like HDGE? what do you think of them? If I understand you correctly, one of the reasons you oppose options is because they are wasting assets or, as you put it, " designed to lose money." this is true, but it seems to me there is a time element that can work against you in all investments; it is just that this is an essential component of an options trade. But what about the time element in other trades? When you talk about shorting you say you wait it out "without time limit." How can this be? Time comes into shorting the underlying as well, because you can never know for sure what the market is going to do. That's why most short traders do close out a position in a certain amount of time or at a certain percentage if a trade goes against them. You are the first I have heard of who shorts "without time limit." I agree that the market looks like it's near a top, but no one knows. What do you do if AMZN keeps going up for the next five years and never comes down? Or what if the dog you pick at 10 suddenly shoots up to 30 as a result of some freak news release that never entered into your calculations? Unless you have unlimited funds, time is an issue, because your debt just keeps growing, even on a relatively small position. Then in the event of a market decline when you are making a profit, you also have to time your exit. Very few can correctly time the bottom. After the popping of the net bubble, how many held their AMZN short positions all the way down to 10 to reap maximum profits? I'm sure many got out much too early and made only minimal profits compared to what they might have made if they had waited longer. I don't see how anyone can escape the time issue in the market unless their strategy is "buy and hold forever."

Topic.Title: AAPL book equity growth versus Amazon... Even more evidence of a broken market...

Message.Msg: Its even worse than that Tech. If you subtract the off the balance sheet obligations from each year (below), AMZN true shareholder equity has actually shrunk over that time. While balance sheet BV has increased $1.4B, there off-BS obligations increased by $6.5B over two years, so net actual book decreased by $5.1B!! AMZN 2010 off-BS obligations: $3.6B (10k value less on BS debt) AMZN 2012 off-BS obligations: $10.1B (10k value less on BS debt)

Az worthless az a stok iz, a scam derivative side bet iz even more worthless... So if a stok iz a scam squared then a Leap iz a scam squared, a monthly option iz a scam squared x 12, and a weekly iz a scam squared x 48, which makes optionz in general pretty worthless. Topic.Title: Tech, with amount of time u have spent on this company

Message.Msg: What are you calling a 'fund', tech? Do you know how many fvck in 'fundz' there are on the planet?? ? Sybil iz a 'fund manager', dummy. Sybil managez the the Master Margin Power Trading fund by the good gracez of the kind trading godz. If youre looking for the 'smoking gun' in the Fidelity Large Cap mutual fund then you aint gonna find it... The only thing you'll find iz that in 2005-2007 GE and xom were gobbled up into it like hershy kissez along with the big banks, and in sept 2008- nov 2009 those same stox were unloaded at a STEEP fvck in discount..... FMR active fund managerz doez all the money running for the entire fidelity flagship. Specific retirement fundz just serve az a pool of capital for FMR to money grub with OPMs to buy, sell, loan sharez, and trade optionz. FIdelitiez brokerage sets a floating 'house margin rate, calculates account value and leverage, and accepts trade requests that iz fed back at super high speedz to FMR. Lets put it this way... FMR doesnt need to read a stale short interest report - they get it in real time from their brokerage desk. At FMR option open interest isnt hand calculated and trading at FMR - thats where the bet line iz set based on number crunching bot stats and probablitiez . At FMR they dont care about what long only stox are held in the Fidelity 2030 fund, they buy and manage the stox themselvez and dump them into the 2030 fund themselvez when they are done making coin off of it. Theze are conglomerates, dummy. Do you think that their long only fund manager bot runz a stock?? He haz culpible deniability, he doesnt ask questionz of FMR or care about 'fiduciary responsibility', he doesnt 'actively manage' anything but his payroll and fund processing expensez and control them, he doesnt make wavez or set the world on fire... He's a typical 'manager', dummy... He accepts hiz role az a baggie dumping ground, and he gets paid well to do it because hiz fund iz stuffed with gazillionz of otger peoplez bernanke bux that show up every fvckin pay period like a train on a tight schedule. Dude, you need to figure put how shyt worx if your going to 'blow it wide open', kojack....
